newsitem.title: USA: BPA now says extra AC capacity in Dec unlikely.
newsitem.headline: BPA now says extra AC capacity in Dec unlikely.

text.p: The Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) is "not hopeful at all" of raising capcity on the AC segment of the Pacific Intertie by next month, a company spokeswoman said Friday.
BPA administrator Randall Hardy said at a congressional hearing in Los Angeles last week the federal agency expected to increase capacity on the line to 3,600 megawatts (MW) by mid-December.
He said work to correct voltage support problems at the McNary hydroelectric dam on the Columbia River was near completion.
But the Western System Coordinating Council (WSCC), which oversees operation of the western power grid, says other criteria need to be met, the BPA spokeswoman said Friday.

Capacity on the 4,800 MW AC line, part of the high-voltage system linking the Northwest and Southwest power markets, is currently limited to 3,200 MW north to south and 3,675 MW south to north, according to Bonneville.
The agency still "absolutely hopes" to raise capacity on the AC, as well as DC (direct current), intertie lines in time for next spring's runoff, the BPA spokeswoman said.
"We will have a financial loss" if the lines are not able to carry the large volumes of hydroelectric power generated in the spring, she noted.
Full studies on how to guarantee voltage support on the transmission system are not expected before January.
Power transmissions on the 3,200 DC segment of the line have been capped at 2,000 to 2,200 MW since the August 10 outage, also because of voltage support concerns.
Bonneville expects to release a follow-up study of the outage next week.
